import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import nltk
from nltk.corpus import stopwords
from nltk.tokenize import word\_tokenize
from nltk.probability import FreqDist
from wordcloud import WordCloud

def analyze\_ahd\_data(request\_data):
 # Load the text data set as a Pandas DataFrame
 #df = pd.read\_csv("cleaned\_df\_20.csv", encoding='ISO-8859-1')
 df = pd.DataFrame(request\_data, columns=['Category', 'Description'])
 
 
 # 1. Descriptive statistics
 print(df.describe(include='object'))

 print("\n")
 print("=======================================================")
 print("\n")

 df['text\_data']=df['Description']

 # 2. Word count, word length, character count, and length

 print('Description variable: Word count, word length, character count, and length')
 print("\n")
 df['word\_count'] = df['text\_data'].apply(lambda x: len(str(x).split()))
 df['word\_length'] = df['text\_data'].apply(lambda x: np.mean([len(word) for word in x.split()]))
 df['char\_count'] = df['text\_data'].apply(lambda x: len(str(x)))
 #df['length'] = df['text\_data'].apply(lambda x: len(str(x).split()))
 print(df[['word\_count', 'word\_length', 'char\_count']].describe())

 print("\n\n")
 print("=======================================================")
 print("\n")

 # 3. Part of speech tagging and counts

 print('Part of speech tagging and counts for Description variable')
 print("\n")
 nltk.download('averaged\_perceptron\_tagger')
 df['pos\_tags'] = df['text\_data'].apply(lambda x: nltk.pos\_tag(word\_tokenize(x)))
 tag\_counts = {}
 for row in df['pos\_tags']:
 for word, tag in row:
 if tag not in tag\_counts:
 tag\_counts[tag] = 1
 else:
 tag\_counts[tag] += 1
 #print(tag\_counts)

 # sort tag\_counts in descending order
 sorted\_tag\_counts = dict(sorted(tag\_counts.items(), key=lambda item: item[1], reverse=True))
 print(sorted\_tag\_counts)

 # plot POS tag counts
 plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
 plt.bar(sorted\_tag\_counts.keys(), sorted\_tag\_counts.values(), color='green')
 plt.title('Part of Speech Tagging and Counts')
 plt.xlabel('POS Tag')
 plt.ylabel('Count')
 plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
 plt.show()

 print("\n")
 print("=======================================================")
 print("\n")

 # 4. 20 most common words and plot

 stop\_words = set(stopwords.words('english'))
 df['text\_data'] = df['text\_data'].apply(lambda x: ' '.join([word for word in x.split() if word.lower() not in stop\_words]))
 fdist = FreqDist(df['text\_data'].str.cat(sep=' ').split())
 print('20 most common words for Description variable ')
 print("\n")
 print(fdist.most\_common(20))
 print("\n")
 print('20 most common Words distribution plot for Description variable ')

 # plot 20 most common words
 plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
 plt.bar([x[0] for x in fdist.most\_common(20)], [x[1] for x in fdist.most\_common(20)], color='green')
 plt.title('20 Most Common Words Distribution')
 plt.xlabel('Words')
 plt.ylabel('Count')
 plt.xticks(rotation=45)
 plt.show()

 print("\n")
 print("=======================================================")

 # 5. Rare words distribution and plot
 rare\_words = fdist.hapaxes()
 print('count of rare word: {}'.format(len(rare\_words)))
 print("\n")
 print('Rare words distribution plot for Description variable ')
 fdist\_rare = FreqDist(rare\_words)

 # plot rare words distribution
 plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
 plt.bar([x[0] for x in fdist\_rare.most\_common(20)], [x[1] for x in fdist\_rare.most\_common(20)], color='green')
 plt.xticks(rotation=90)
 plt.title("Rare words distribution plot for Description variable")
 plt.xlabel("Words")
 plt.ylabel("Frequency")
 plt.show()

 print("\n")
 print("=======================================================")

 # 6. Word and character counts by category
 print('Word and character counts by category for Description variable ')
 print("\n")
 category\_counts = df.groupby('Category').agg({'word\_count': 'sum', 'char\_count': 'sum'})

 # plot word and character counts by category
 category\_counts.plot(kind='bar', rot=0, color=['green', 'orange'])
 plt.title("Word and Character Counts by Category for Description variable")
 plt.xlabel("Category")
 plt.ylabel("Count")
 plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
 plt.show()

 print("\n")
 print("=======================================================")
 print("\n")

 # 7. Word cloud for each category
 print('Category wise Wordcloud ')
 print("\n")

 categories = df['Category'].unique()

 # create subplots for wordclouds
 #fig, axs = plt.subplots(nrows=1, ncols=len(categories), figsize=(20, 8))

 # for i, category in enumerate(categories):
 # text = ' '.join(df[df['Category'] == category]['text\_data'].tolist())
 # wordcloud = WordCloud(width = 800, height = 800,
 # background\_color ='white',
 # stopwords = stop\_words,
 # min\_font\_size = 10).generate(text)
 # axs[i].imshow(wordcloud) 
 # axs[i].axis("off") 
 # axs[i].set\_title(category)
 # plt.tight\_layout(pad=0)
 # plt.show()

 for i in range(0, len(categories), 2):
 plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
 for j, category in enumerate(categories[i:i+2]):
 plt.subplot(1, 2, j+1)
 text = ' '.join(df[df['Category'] == category]['text\_data'].tolist())
 wordcloud = WordCloud(width=1000, height=600, background\_color='white', stopwords=stop\_words, min\_font\_size=10).generate(text)
 plt.imshow(wordcloud)
 plt.axis('off')

Apologies for the interruption, here is the complete SQL code to create the necessary tables and populate them with sample data:
```sql
CREATE TABLE Restaurant (
  restaurant_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(255),
  location VARCHAR(255),
  contact_details VARCHAR(255),
  branch_id INT
);

CREATE TABLE Queue (
  queue_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  restaurant_id INT,
  status VARCHAR(255),
  expected_waiting_time INT,
  period_id INT,
  FOREIGN KEY (restaurant_id) REFERENCES Restaurant(restaurant_id),
  FOREIGN KEY (period_id) REFERENCES Period(period_id)
);

CREATE TABLE Customer (
  customer_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  queue_id INT,
  name VARCHAR(255),
  contact_details VARCHAR(255),
  time_joined DATETIME,
  FOREIGN KEY (queue_id) REFERENCES Queue(queue_id)
);

CREATE TABLE Table (
  table_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  restaurant_id INT,
  table_number INT,
  seats INT,
  status VARCHAR(255),
  FOREIGN KEY (restaurant_id) REFERENCES Restaurant(restaurant_id)
);

CREATE TABLE Branch (
  branch_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(255),
  location VARCHAR(255),
  contact_details VARCHAR(255),
  FOREIGN KEY (restaurant_id) REFERENCES Restaurant(restaurant_id)
);

CREATE TABLE Period (
  period_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  start_time DATETIME,
  end_time DATETIME,
  wait_time_in_minutes INT
);

CREATE TABLE queue_table (
  queue_id INT,
  table_id INT,
  PRIMARY KEY (queue_id, table_id),
  FOREIGN KEY (queue_id) REFERENCES Queue(queue_id),
  FOREIGN KEY (table_id) REFERENCES Table(table_id)
);

It defines the `Billing` model as its model. 2. It includes only the `levy_type`, `amount`, and `due_date` fields. 3. When it comes to culinary traditions, every country has a unique story to tell. From the spices used to the cooking techniques employed, food is one of the most important ways in which culture is expressed. In this blog post, we will explore the culinary traditions of ten different countries, from the staple foods to the key dishes of different courses.

United Kingdom
--------------

The United Kingdom, which comprises Scotland, Wales, England, and Ireland, has a rich culinary heritage influenced by its colonial past. Lard is a predominant cooking medium, while pies and pastries are popular. Sausages like Haggis are widespread, and alcoholic spirits are predominantly used as an aid to cooking. The staple foods of the UK include offal, meat, milk, vegetables like leeks, onions, garlic, and leeks, butter, cheese, oats, barley, and potatoes. Some of the most important dishes of different courses include fish and chips, shepherd's pie, cornish pastry, Yorkshire pudding, Welsh rarebit, roast beef, Cumberland sausage, bread and butter pudding, scones, and fruit trifle.

Italy
-----

Italian cuisine is one of the most popular in the world, characterized by its use of olive oil, wine, and starch-based products like pasta, pizza, and bread. Coffee, specifically espresso, is served after meals, and Italian meals are accompanied by wine. Tomatoes, durum wheat, olive oil, cheese, meat, poultry, and herbs like basil, oregano, and thyme are some of the most important ingredients in Italian cuisine. Some of the most important dishes of different courses include minestrone, frito miso, polenta, pizza, spaghetti carbonara, tiramisu, panettone, bisttecca alla florentina, zabaglione, and ricotta gnudi.

France
------

French cuisine is characterized by its finesse and attention to detail. Baked goods are widely used, and stock serves as an important base for most sauces and all soups. Garnishes and accompaniments are very important, and the courses and structure of the menu are adhered to strictly. The most important ingredients in French cuisine include eggs, herbs, mustard, wine, bread, meat, poultry, seafood, and stock. Some of the most important dishes of different courses include moules et frites, chicken cordon bleu, mussels a la mariniere, beef bourguignon, pork tenderloin, coq au vin, poulet parisienne, salmon and swiss chard quiche, mille-feuille, and creme brulee.

Spain
-----

Spanish cuisine is characterized by its use of various condiments and spices, as well as its large midday meal known as la comida. Snacks and appetizers referred to as tapas are extremely popular, and large amounts of tomatoes are used in many dishes. Saffron is used to flavor many dishes. The staple foods of Spain include tomatoes, milk, seafood, meat, poultry, rice, olive oil, and forcemeat. Some of the most important dishes of different courses include gazpacho, tortillas, pintxos, paella, cat soup, ox-tail stew, cod tava, churros, flan, and torrija.

Portugal
--------

Portuguese cuisine is heavily influenced by the colonial era and Mediterranean influences. Seafood is consumed in large quantities, and spices like peri-peri are widely used. Herbs like bay leaves and parsley are important, and olive oil is the basis of most dishes. The

Here are some of the top NumPy functions with examples and code in Python:

1. `np.array()`: Creates a NumPy array from a Python list.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array from a Python list
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.arange()`: Creates a NumPy array with evenly spaced values within a specified range.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array with values from 0 to 9
arr = np.arange(10)

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.linspace()`: Creates a NumPy array with evenly spaced values within a specified interval.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array with 10 values between 0 and 1
arr = np.linspace(0, 1, 10)

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.zeros()`: Creates a NumPy array filled with zeros.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array filled with zeros
arr = np.zeros((3, 3))

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.ones()`: Creates a NumPy array filled with ones.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array filled with ones
arr = np.ones((3, 3))

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.eye()`: Creates a NumPy array with ones on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a 3x3 identity matrix
arr = np.eye(3)

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.random.rand()`: Creates a NumPy array with random values between 0 and 1.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a 2x2 array with random values between 0 and 1
arr = np.random.rand(2, 2)

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.random.randint()`: Creates a NumPy array with random integers within a specified range.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a 2x2 array with random integers between 0 and 9
arr = np.random.randint(0, 10, size=(2, 2))

# display the array
print(arr)
```
1. `np.sum()`: Calculates the sum of the values in a NumPy array.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

# calculate the sum of the array
sum = np.sum(arr)

# display the sum
print(sum)
```
1. `np.mean()`: Calculates the mean of the values in a NumPy array.
```python
import numpy as np

# create a NumPy array
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

# calculate the mean of the array
mean = np.mean(arr)

# display the mean
print(mean)
```

Chatbots with a Brain: How AI-Enhanced Customer Service is Changing the Game

Customer service has always been a vital part of any business, and with the rise of technology, it has undergone significant changes. One of the most notable changes is the use of chatbots, which are automated tools that can assist customers with their queries and problems. However, with the help of artificial intelligence (AI), chatbots are becoming smarter and more sophisticated, offering a personalized and seamless experience to customers. In this blog post, we'll explore how AI-enhanced customer service is changing the game for businesses and customers alike.

What are Chatbots with a Brain?

Chatbots with a Brain refers to the use of AI-powered chatbots in customer service. These chatbots are equipped with natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning algorithms that enable them to understand and respond to customers' queries and concerns in a human-like manner. These chatbots can also learn from previous interactions and improve their responses over time, making them more effective and efficient in handling customer requests.

The Benefits of AI-Enhanced Customer Service

AI-enhanced customer service has several benefits for both businesses and customers. One of the most significant advantages is the ability to offer personalized and seamless experiences to customers. With the help of AI, chatbots can analyze customer data and provide tailored recommendations and solutions, enhancing the customer experience and driving customer satisfaction.

Another significant advantage of AI-enhanced customer service is the ability to reduce wait times and handle a high volume of requests simultaneously. Chatbots can handle multiple customer requests simultaneously, ensuring that customers receive timely responses and reducing the need for human intervention.

The Challenges of AI-Enhanced Customer Service

While AI-enhanced customer service has several benefits, there are also some challenges that businesses need to address. One of the main challenges is the potential for chatbots to lack empathy and understanding of complex customer issues. While AI algorithms can learn from previous interactions and improve their responses, they may not be able to handle complex or emotional issues that require human empathy and understanding.

Another challenge is the potential for data privacy and security issues. Chatbots collect and store customer data, raising concerns about data privacy and security. Businesses need to ensure that they have proper security measures in place to protect customer data and comply with data protection regulations.

The Future of AI-Enhanced Customer Service

As businesses continue to invest in AI-enhanced customer service, the role of chatbots with a Brain will only continue to grow. Businesses that are able to successfully leverage AI technology to enhance their customer service capabilities will be well-positioned to gain a competitive edge in the market.

However, to succeed in this space, businesses need to be aware of the limitations of chatbots with a Brain and take steps to ensure that they are still able to provide a human touch when needed. Businesses need to invest in training their customer service representatives to work alongside chatbots to provide a seamless and personalized customer experience.

Conclusion

AI-enhanced customer service is transforming the way businesses interact with customers, providing a personalized and seamless experience that enhances customer satisfaction and drives business growth. With the right investment in technology and training, businesses can leverage AI to improve their customer service capabilities and gain a competitive edge in the market. The future of AI-enhanced customer service looks bright, and businesses and customers alike can look forward to an exciting new era of customer service.

Summary:
WaveNet is a deep generative model for raw audio waveforms, developed by researchers at DeepMind. The model is based on dilated convolutions, which allow the receptive field to grow exponentially with the depth of the network, while keeping the computational cost constant. The model generates high-quality speech and music samples that are nearly indistinguishable from real recordings. WaveNet has been used for a variety of applications, including text-to-speech synthesis, music generation, and voice conversion.

Main Architecture:
The main architecture of WaveNet consists of a stack of causal dilated convolutions, which operate on the raw audio waveform in an autoregressive manner. The network takes as input a sequence of raw audio samples and predicts the distribution of the next sample at each time step. The output distribution is then sampled to obtain the next sample, which is fed back into the network as input for the next time step.

The dilated convolutions in WaveNet have a special structure, where the filter weights are shared across time and across channels, but are multiplied by a different set of coefficients at each time step, determined by a set of learnable gating functions. This allows the network to capture long-range dependencies in the audio signal, while avoiding the computational cost of a fully connected network. The network also uses skip connections to bypass several layers at a time, allowing the output of one block of dilated convolutions to be added to the output of an earlier block, and fed as input to a later block.

Main Code:
Here's some sample code for a simplified version of the WaveNet architecture using Keras:
```python
from tensorflow.keras.layers import Input, Conv1D, Multiply, Add, Activation
from tensorflow.keras.models import Model

def build_wavenet(input_shape, num_filters=128, num_layers=10, num_dilation_rates=3):
    inputs = Input(shape=input_shape)

    # Initial convolutional layer
    x = Conv1D(num_filters, kernel_size=2, padding='causal')(inputs)

    # Stack of dilated convolutional layers
    for i in range(num_layers):
        for j in range(num_dilation_rates):
            # Dilated convolutional layer with exponentially increasing dilation rate
            dilation_rate = 2 ** j
            x1 = Conv1D(num_filters, kernel_size=2, padding='causal', dilation_rate=dilation_rate)(x)

            # Gating function
            x2 = Conv1D(num_filters, kernel_size=2, padding='causal', dilation_rate=dilation_rate)(x)
            x2 = Activation('sigmoid')(x2)

            # Element-wise multiplication and addition
            x = Multiply()([x1, x2])
            x = Add()([x, inputs if j == 0 else skip])

            # Skip connection
            if j == num_dilation_rates - 1:
                skip = Conv1D(num_filters, kernel_size=1)(x)
                inputs = skip if i == 0 else Add()([inputs, skip])

    # Final convolutional and output layers
    x = Activation('relu')(inputs)
    x = Conv1D(num_filters, kernel_size=1)(x)
    x = Activation('relu')(x)
    x = Conv1D(1, kernel_size=1)(x)

    model = Model(inputs=inputs, outputs=x, name='WaveNet')
    return model
```
This code builds a WaveNet model that takes as input a sequence of raw audio samples, represented as a 1D array, and outputs a probability distribution over the next sample. The `num_filters` argument controls the number of filters in each convolutional layer, while `num

Due to the extensive nature of the codes above, it may not be feasible to integrate all of them as one single code. Each use case has its unique requirements and implementation details that are specific to the task at hand. It would be best to keep the codes separate, organized, and modular for easy maintenance and updates.

However, it is possible to combine some codes into a single program if they have similar functionalities. For example, the drone control and obstacle avoidance codes can be combined into a single program that allows the drone to avoid obstacles and navigate autonomously.

In general, it is recommended to use a programming language that supports object-oriented programming and modularity to facilitate the organization and integration of the codes. Python is an excellent choice due to its readability, ease of use, and extensive libraries for various tasks.

Here is an example of how the code for drone control and obstacle avoidance can be combined:
```python
import RPi.GPIO as GPIO
import time

# Set up GPIO pins
GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BOARD)
GPIO.setup(11, GPIO.OUT)  # Motor 1
GPIO.setup(13, GPIO.OUT)  # Motor 2
GPIO.setup(15, GPIO.OUT)  # Motor 3
GPIO.setup(16, GPIO.OUT)  # Motor 4
GPIO.setup(18, GPIO.IN)  # Obstacle sensor

# Set up PWM for motor control
p1 = GPIO.PWM(11, 50)
p2 = GPIO.PWM(13, 50)
p3 = GPIO.PWM(15, 50)
p4 = GPIO.PWM(16, 50)
p1.start(0)
p2.start(0)
p3.start(0)
p4.start(0)

# Set up speed and direction for each motor
def set_speed(motor, speed):
    motor.ChangeDutyCycle(speed)

def set_direction(motor, direction):
    if direction == 'forward':
        GPIO.output(motor, GPIO.HIGH)
    else:
        GPIO.output(motor, GPIO.LOW)

# Move the drone forward
def move_forward(speed):
    set_speed(p1, speed)
    set_speed(p2, speed)
    set_speed(p3, speed)
    set_speed(p4, speed)
    set_direction(11, 'forward')
    set_direction(13, 'forward')
    set_direction(15, 'backward')
    set_direction(16, 'backward')

# Move the drone backward
def move_backward(speed):
    set_speed(p1, speed)
    set_speed(p2, speed)
    set_speed(p3, speed)
    set_speed(p4, speed)
    set_direction(11, 'backward')
    set_direction(13, 'backward')
    set_direction(15, 'forward')
    set_direction(16, 'forward')

# Stop the drone
def stop():
    set_speed(p1, 0)
    set_speed(p2, 0)
    set_speed(p3, 0)
    set_speed(p4, 0)

# Detect obstacles
def detect_obstacle():
    if GPIO.input(18):
        return True
    else:
        return False

# Main program loop
try:
    while True:
        if detect_obstacle():
            move_backward(50)
            time.sleep(1)
            stop()
        else:
            move_forward(50)

# Clean up GPIO pins
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    GPIO.cleanup()
```
This code uses the Raspberry Pi GPIO pins to control the drone's motors and detect obstacles using an infrared sensor. When an obstacle is detected, the drone will move backward for one second and stop. Otherwise, it will move forward at a speed of 50% PWM duty cycle.

The CADF (Cointegrated Augmented Dickey-Fuller) test is a statistical test used to check for the presence of cointegration between two time series. It is a modification of the traditional ADF (Augmented Dickey-Fuller) test that accounts for the possibility of cointegration between the two series.

To check for cointegration using the CADF test, we first need to test each time series for stationarity using the ADF test. If one or both series are non-stationary, we can take their first differences to make them stationary. We then regress one time series on the other using ordinary least squares (OLS) and obtain the residuals.

We then perform the CADF test on the residuals to determine if they are stationary and hence whether the two series are cointegrated. The null hypothesis of the CADF test is that the residuals contain a unit root, which indicates that the two series are not cointegrated. The alternative hypothesis is that the residuals are stationary, which indicates that the two series are cointegrated.

Here is some sample Python code to check for cointegration using the CADF test:
```python
import pandas as pd
from statsmodels.tsa.stattools import adfuller
from statsmodels.regression.linear_model import OLS
from statsmodels.tsa.stattools import adfuller
from statsmodels.tsa.stattools import coint

# Load time series data
y = pd.read_csv('y.csv', index_col='Date', parse_dates=True)
x = pd.read_csv('x.csv', index_col='Date', parse_dates=True)

# Check for stationarity of the time series using the ADF test
adf_y = adfuller(y)
adf_x = adfuller(x)

if adf_y[1] < 0.05 and adf_x[1] < 0.05:
    print('Time series are stationary')
else:
    y_diff = y.diff().dropna()
    x_diff = x.diff().dropna()
    print('Time series are non-stationary')
    
    # Check for stationarity of the differenced time series
    adf_y_diff = adfuller(y_diff)
    adf_x_diff = adfuller(x_diff)

    if adf_y_diff[1] < 0.05 and adf_x_diff[1] < 0.05:
        print('Differenced time series are stationary')
        y = y_diff
        x = x_diff
    else:
        print('Differenced time series are also non-stationary')

# Regress one time series on the other using OLS
model = OLS(y, x).fit()
residuals = model.resid

# Check for cointegration using the CADF test
cadf = coint(y, x)
if cadf[1] < 0.05:
    print('Time series are cointegrated')
else:
    print('Time series are not cointegrated')
```
In this code, we first load two time series (y and x) into separate Pandas DataFrames. We then use the ADF test to check for stationarity of the time series, and if necessary, take their first differences to make them stationary.

We then use OLS to regress one time series on the other and obtain the residuals. Finally, we perform the CADF test on the residuals to determine if the two time series are cointegrated or not.

If the CADF test statistic is less than the critical value at the 5% significance level, we reject the null hypothesis of no cointegration and conclude that the two series are cointegrated. Otherwise, we fail to reject the

Sure, I can help you with that. ARIMA (Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average) models are a popular choice for time series forecasting, and they are especially useful when there is evidence of seasonality in the data.

To start with, let's plot the data to visualize the trend and seasonality, and to identify any outliers or other anomalies.
```bash
library(ggplot2)

# Create a data frame with the median sale price data
df <- data.frame(
  date = as.Date(c("2021-09-01", "2021-10-01", "2021-11-01", "2021-12-01", "2022-01-01", "2022-02-01", "2022-03-01", "2022-04-01", "2022-05-01", "2022-06-01", "2022-07-01", "2022-08-01", "2022-09-01", "2022-10-01", "2022-11-01", "2022-12-01")),
  median_price = c(503.15, 519, 528.9, 541.62, 561, 569.075, 584.52, 595.21, 602.55, 615.9, 629, 649, 654.05, 672.5, 675, 675)
)

# Plot the median sale price data
ggplot(df, aes(x = date, y = median_price)) +
  geom_line() +
  ggtitle("Median Sale Price of Burpengary Property (Sep 2021 - Dec 2022)") +
  xlab("Date") +
  ylab("Median Sale Price (Thousands of Dollars)")
```
Based on the plot, there seems to be an upward trend in the median sale price, with some seasonality evident in the data as well. There are no major outliers or anomalies that we need to worry about.

Now, we can fit an ARIMA model to the data using the `forecast` package in R. To determine the optimal values of the ARIMA parameters (p, d, and q), we can use the `auto.arima()` function, which automatically selects the best model based on the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC).
```bash
library(forecast)

# Fit an ARIMA model to the median sale price data
arima_model <- auto.arima(df$median_price)

# Print the summary of the ARIMA model
summary(arima_model)
```
The `auto.arima()` function has chosen an ARIMA(2,1,2) model, which means that the model includes two autoregressive terms, one differencing term, and two moving average terms.

We can now use the `forecast()` function to generate forecasts for the next few periods. For example, to generate forecasts for the next 12 months, we can use the following code:
```python
# Generate forecasts for the next 12 months
forecast_values <- forecast(arima_model, h = 12)

# Print the forecast values
print(forecast_values)
```
The `forecast()` function generates forecasts for the next 12 months, along with prediction intervals for each forecast. The forecast values and prediction intervals are stored in the `forecast_values` object, which we can print to the console to see the results.

3.1. Machine Learning and Deep Learning in Retrosynthetic Analysis

In recent years, machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques have emerged as powerful tools to address the limitations of manual retrosynthetic analysis and traditional computational methods. These data-driven approaches can learn complex patterns and relationships from large chemical datasets, enabling more accurate and efficient predictions of retrosynthetic routes (86, 87). This section discusses the application of ML and DL in retrosynthetic analysis, highlighting key advancements and methodologies.

1. Neural network models: Neural networks, particularly deep learning models like convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs), have been applied to predict retrosynthetic routes by learning complex representations of molecular structures and reaction patterns (88, 89). For example, the work by Segler et al. (90) employed a combination of CNNs and RNNs to predict suitable precursors for a given target molecule.
2. Sequence-to-sequence models: Sequence-to-sequence models, which are typically based on RNNs and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks, have been applied to translate molecular representations of target compounds into precursor molecules, mimicking the process of retrosynthetic disconnection (91, 92). The work by Liu et al. (93) used a sequence-to-sequence model to predict high-level disconnection patterns for a given target molecule.
3. Graph convolutional networks (GCNs): GCNs have been used to model molecular graphs for predicting retrosynthetic routes, taking advantage of their ability to capture local and global structural features of molecules (94, 95). For instance, Coley et al. (96) developed a graph-convolutional approach to predict retrosynthetic routes by learning a continuous representation of molecular structures and reaction templates.
4. Reinforcement learning (RL): RL techniques, such as Q-learning and deep Q-networks (DQNs), have been applied to retrosynthetic analysis by modeling the disconnection process as a decision-making problem, where the algorithm iteratively learns the optimal actions to perform at each step (97, 98). The work by Zhou et al. (99) employed a DQN-based approach to navigate the retrosynthetic tree and identify efficient synthetic routes.
5. Transfer learning: Transfer learning techniques have been used to leverage pre-trained models and knowledge from related tasks to improve the performance of retrosynthetic analysis models, particularly when training data is limited (100, 101). The work by Schwaller et al. (102) demonstrated the effectiveness of transfer learning in predicting reaction templates for retrosynthetic disconnections.
6. Multi-task learning: Multi-task learning methods, which involve training a single model to perform multiple tasks simultaneously, have been used to improve the accuracy and generalizability of retrosynthetic analysis models by leveraging the shared knowledge between related tasks (103, 104). An example of this approach can be found in the work by Dai et al. (105), where a single model was trained to predict multiple reaction outcomes, such as yield and selectivity, in addition to retrosynthetic routes.

The application of ML and DL in retrosynthetic analysis has shown significant promise in overcoming the limitations of manual methods and traditional computational approaches, enabling the development of more accurate, efficient, and scalable tools for synthetic route prediction (106, 107).

import cv2

# Define a function to store drone data in the database
def store_data(latitude, longitude, altitude, temperature, humidity):
    conn.execute('INSERT INTO drone_data (latitude, longitude, altitude, temperature, humidity) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)', (latitude, longitude, altitude, temperature, humidity))

# Open the video stream
cap = cv2.VideoCapture(0)

while True:
    # Read a frame from the video stream
    ret, frame = cap.read()
    
    # Detect objects in the frame using YOLO
    height, width, channels = frame.shape
    blob = cv2.dnn.blobFromImage(frame, 0.00392, (416, 416), (0, 0, 0), True, crop=False)
    net.setInput(blob)

    # Process the detected objects

            scores = detection[5:]
            class_id = np.argmax(scores)
            confidence = scores[class_id]
            if confidence > 0.5:
                # Get the coordinates of the bounding box around the object
                center_x = int(detection[0] * width)
                center_y = int(detection[1] * height)
                w = int(detection[2] * width)
                h = int(detection[3] * height)
                x = int(center_x - w / 2)
                y = int(center_y - h / 2)
                
                # Draw the bounding box around the object
                cv2.rectangle(frame, (x, y), (x + w, y + h), (0, 255, 0), 2)
                
                # Get the GPS coordinates and altitude of the object
                latitude, longitude, altitude = get_coordinates(x, y, w, h)
                
                # Get the temperature and humidity of the object
                temperature, humidity = get_environmental_data(latitude, longitude, altitude)
                
                # Store the drone data in the database
                store_data(latitude, longitude, altitude, temperature, humidity)
    
    # Display the frame
    cv2.imshow('frame', frame)
    
    # Exit if the user presses the 'q' key
    if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'):
        break

# Release the video stream and close the window
cap.release()
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
```

Sure, I have added the given function `nltk_tag_to_wordnet()` and `get_lemmatized()` to the `clean_text()` function. Here's the updated `clean_text()` function:
```python
import string
import nltk
import pandas as pd
from nltk.tokenize import word_tokenize
from nltk.probability import FreqDist
from nltk.corpus import stopwords
from nltk.corpus import wordnet
from nltk.stem import WordNetLemmatizer 

def clean_text(text):
    # convert text to lowercase
    text = text.lower()
    # remove punctuation
    text = text.translate(str.maketrans('', '', string.punctuation))
    # tokenize the text and remove stopwords
    tokens = word_tokenize(text)
    stop_words = set(stopwords.words('english'))
    filtered_tokens = [token for token in tokens if token not in stop_words]
    # lemmatize the text
    tagged_tokens = nltk.pos_tag(filtered_tokens)
    lemmatizer = WordNetLemmatizer()
    lemmatized_tokens = [lemmatizer.lemmatize(token[0], pos=nltk_tag_to_wordnet(token[1])) if nltk_tag_to_wordnet(token[1]) is not None else lemmatizer.lemmatize(token[0]) for token in tagged_tokens]
    # join the tokens back into a string
    text = ' '.join(lemmatized_tokens)
    return text
```

Sure! Here's an example of how you could use deep learning techniques to perform topic modeling on the article data:
```makefile
import requests
import nltk
import gensim
from gensim import corpora
from nltk.corpus import stopwords

# Define the API endpoint and search parameters
endpoint_url = "https://api.alpha-sense.com/v1/search"
api_key = "your_api_key"
url = endpoint_url + "?key=" + api_key

search_params = {
    "query": "semiconductor AND market outlook",
    "published": "last_3_months",
    "entity_types": "companies",
    "limit": 100,
    "offset": 0
}

# Send the API request and retrieve the data
response = requests.get(url, params=search_params)
data = response.json()

# Tokenize the article text and remove stop words
stop_words = set(stopwords.words('english'))
texts = []
for article in data["results"]:
    content = article["content"]
    tokens = nltk.word_tokenize(content)
    filtered_tokens = [word.lower() for word in tokens if word.lower() not in stop_words]
    texts.append(filtered_tokens)

# Create a dictionary and corpus for the topic model
dictionary = corpora.Dictionary(texts)
corpus = [dictionary.doc2bow(text) for text in texts]

# Train the topic model
num_topics = 5
lda_model = gensim.models.LdaMulticore(corpus=corpus, id2word=dictionary, num_topics=num_topics)

# Print the top topics and their associated keywords
for topic in lda_model.print_topics(num_words=10):
    print(topic)
```
In this example, we first import the necessary libraries, including `gensim` for topic modeling and `stopwords` from the `nltk` library for removing common stop words from the text.

We then iterate through the articles in the API response and tokenize the article text using `nltk.word_tokenize()` and remove stop words using a list comprehension. We store the resulting tokenized text in a list called `texts`.

Next, we create a dictionary and corpus for the topic model using the `Dictionary()` and `corpora` modules from `gensim`. The `Dictionary()` method creates a mapping of words to numeric IDs, and the `doc2bow()` method converts the tokenized text to bag-of-words format.

We then train the topic model using the `LdaMulticore()` method from `gensim`, which uses a form of unsupervised learning to identify patterns in the text data and group similar articles into topics. In this example, we set the number of topics to 5.

Finally, we print the top topics and their associated keywords using the `print_topics()` method of the trained model. The `num_words` argument specifies the number of top keywords to include for each topic.

You can experiment with different numbers of topics and keywords to refine the results and get more meaningful insights from the article data. Additionally, you can use other deep learning techniques such as text classification or sentiment analysis to extract more insights from the text data.

    confidences = []
    boxes = []

            scores = detection[5:]
            class_id = np.argmax(scores)
            confidence = scores[class_id]

                center_y = int(detection[1] * frame.shape[0])

                h = int(detection[3] * frame.shape[0])

To add a "Run Weekly Allowance" button to the settings page and create allowance events for each category, follow these steps:

1. Add the button to the `app/views/settings/edit.html.erb` file:
```html
<!-- ... -->

<%= form_with(url: run_weekly_allowance_settings_path, method: 'post', local: true) do |form| %>
  <%= form.submit 'Run Weekly Allowance' %>
<% end %>

<!-- ... -->
```
This code adds a new form that submits a POST request to the `run_weekly_allowance` action in the `SettingsController`.

1. Update the `config/routes.rb` file to add the new route:
```ruby
# ...

resources :settings, only: [:edit, :update] do
  post 'run_weekly_allowance', on: :collection
end

# ...
```
This code adds a new route for the `run_weekly_allowance` action in the `SettingsController`.

1. Add the `run_weekly_allowance` action to the `SettingsController`:
```ruby
class SettingsController < ApplicationController
  # ...

  def run_weekly_allowance
    if allowance_not_given_since_previous_monday?
      create_allowance_events
      redirect_to edit_settings_path, notice: 'Weekly allowance has been run successfully.'
    else
      redirect_to edit_settings_path, alert: 'Weekly allowance has already been run since the previous Monday.'
    end
  end

  private

  # ...

  def allowance_not_given_since_previous_monday?
    previous_monday = Date.today.beginning_of_week - 1.week
    AllowanceEvent.where(event_type: ['spending', 'savings', 'giving'])
                  .where('timestamp >= ?', previous_monday)
                  .empty?
  end

  def create_allowance_events
    weekly_allowance = {
      spending: AllowanceSetting.find_by(category: 'spending')&.amount || 0,
      savings: AllowanceSetting.find_by(category: 'savings')&.amount || 0,
      giving: AllowanceSetting.find_by(category: 'giving')&.amount || 0
    }

    weekly_allowance.each do |category, amount|
      AllowanceEvent.create!(
        event_type: category,
        amount: amount,
        timestamp: Time.current
      )
    end
  end
end
```
This code adds the `run_weekly_allowance` action to the `SettingsController`. This action checks if there have been any allowance events since the previous Monday using the `allowance_not_given_since_previous_monday?` helper method. If no allowance events are found, the action creates allowance events for each category using the `create_allowance_events` helper method and displays a success message. If allowance events have already been run since the previous Monday, it displays an error message.

1. Modify the `AllowanceEvent` model to include a validation for `timestamp`:
```ruby
class AllowanceEvent < ApplicationRecord
  # ...

  validates :timestamp, presence: true
end
```
This code adds a validation to the `AllowanceEvent` model to ensure that the `timestamp` attribute is present when creating a new record.

CHAPTER THIRTEEN
 RULE #5
 Use the Power in Your Posterior
 From Jeremy
Possibly the most overlooked bit of anatomy, for back pain, is your backside. We are talking about your butt and especially your glutes, the big muscles that constitute most of your butt. The difficulty is that, in modern times, we have mostly used our glutes to sit on. They have atrophied as a result. The use of the buttocks exclusively as a seat cushion is a recent development in evolutionary terms, and a rotten one. It is handy, lord knows, but that wasn’t the original design idea, and we are paying a horrendous price for it, mostly in back pain. 
Letting your glutes go to hell in idleness (“gluteal amnesia,” as the great student of back pain Dr. Stuart McGill called it) is an absolutely dreadful idea. By all means, continue to sit on them. But do much, much more, too. Remember that the glutes are the biggest muscles in your body, they have serious loads to bear, and it is critical that we let them do it. Because, if we don’t, our spines (and the tiny muscles around them) will carry those loads, and they are not designed for it. They protest . . . they hurt. And they will continue to hurt until you wake up your glutes and let them do their job. 
The gluteal muscles are a group of three muscles that make up the buttocks. There are several smaller muscles back there as well, including the piriformis. They look like this (see diagram below). 
In a healthy person, the gluteal muscles perform a bunch of important functions. Here’s what they should be doing: 
• helping you to stand up and maintain erect posture 
• keeping you from falling forward when you walk or run 
• keeping your pelvis from collapsing when you are standing on one leg or walking when only one foot is in contact with the ground 
• helping you to rise from a seated position 
• helping you pick things up 
• helping you climb stairs, ski, run, row—and that old favorite, make love
Gluteal Muscles

All kinds of things. Obviously, these are some of the most important things you do and these are some of the most important muscles in your body. 
When you let your glutes go to sleep, things get bad. They “forget” all those critical functions, and the muscles that take up the slack are not up to the job. As we compress the muscles (by sitting on them), nerves and blood vessels in the gluteal muscle don’t work as well. Our brain literally loses its connectivity with them. The muscles, and the neural pathways, atrophy (or “lose preference”); the brain “forgets” them. Hence, the term gluteal amnesia. In my experience, there is a very high correlation between the glutes going to sleep and back pain. Very high.
Here’s why: When those big powerful muscles aren’t doing their job, the spine takes over. It bears the brunt of the forces that the glutes are supposed to be handling and it gets overwhelmed and damaged. Instead of using those big muscles to do things like pick up your child or grandchild, you first use the tiny muscles around your spine to do them, and those muscles can’t handle it. They become strained (which causes pain, all by itself) and eventually fail. Then things get quite a bit worse. When those little muscles fail, the forces that your glutes were supposed to be handling get transmitted directly onto your discs, joints, ligaments, and tendons. That is not what they are supposed to do and it causes serious problems. Conversely, those big psoas muscles get reflexively tighter, putting more pressure on the spine. Think about it: Every time you get out of a chair, pick something up, tie your shoe, or climb the stairs, you are putting a ton of pressure on your spine that it is not designed to bear. You can do it for a while. You can do almost anything for a while. But over the days, months, and years, these micro irritations add up to macro damage. Remember Chris’s explanation of “geologic time”? Mountains are ground down to rubble in geologic time. Your spine is ground down to rubble in your own version of geologic time, if your glutes don’t do their job.
Summary: Letting your glutes go to sleep is a terrible idea. Reversing that process and waking them up is crucial to healing back pain. Once those muscles wake up and start doing their intended work, the muscles that do the opposite motion on the joint, the psoas muscles, reflexively loosen up. If you didn’t know this, don’t feel bad. A lot of therapists and doctors don’t know it, either. Or don’t treat it effectively. Teaching you how to treat the problem effectively is one of the most important things we do in this book. 
Here’s what you need to do, in three steps: Wake up your glutes, make them strong, and learn to use them at the appropriate times, as they were designed to be used. 
PART ONE: WAKING UP THE SLEEPING GIANTS
You tried using your glutes with the bridge exercise. Now let’s try a different way to wake them up. If you had trouble with the bridge, don’t worry. We will come back to that shortly. 
Clamshell
Now, on to the all-important “clamshell” exercise. It is critical—boring and often poorly performed, but it wakes up and strengthens your glutes.
Step 1: Lie on your side with your hips and knees bent as shown.
Step 2: Take the thumb of your top hand and dig it inside your upper hip bone, as in the drawing. 
Step 3: Lay the four fingers of that hand across the outside of your hip, as in the picture. 
Step 4: For most of you, your middle finger (or first or third) will be lying right on the gluteal muscles we are trying to wake up. Poke your fingers in there and feel them. Reestablish that connection with your brain. Keep your fingers there.

Step 5: Find your neutral spine and brace your core.

Inputs:

* User's identification documents (e.g. passport, driver's license, etc.)
* User's personal information (if available)

Outputs:

* User's digital identity stored on a blockchain
1. User navigates to the registration website and clicks "Register" button.
2. System captures the user's IP address and device information (e.g. browser type, screen resolution, etc.).
3. System prompts the user to upload their identification documents.
4. User uploads their identification documents and clicks "Next" button.
5. System uses machine learning and optical character recognition (OCR) to extract data from the identification documents. This includes the user's name, date of birth, address, document number, and other relevant data.
6. System cross-checks the extracted data with government records or other trusted sources to validate the identification documents.
7. If the identification documents are invalid, the registration process is terminated. Otherwise, the system continues to the next step.
8. System creates a new public/private key pair for the user.
9. System associates the user's public key with their personal information and identification documents, and generates a unique ID for the user.
10. If the user's personal information was not provided in step 1, the system uses machine learning to extract personal information from the identification documents. This includes the user's name, date of birth, address, and other relevant data.
11. System creates a digital identity for the user and stores it on a blockchain.
12. System sends a confirmation email to the user's registered email address to verify their email address.
13. User clicks on the verification link in the confirmation email to confirm their email address.
14. System verifies the email address by checking the verification link. If email address is invalid, the registration process is terminated.
15. System prompts the user to complete a two-factor authentication (2FA) process, which requires them to provide a second form of verification (e.g. SMS code, voice call, authentication app, etc.).
16. System uses risk-based authentication to assess the level of risk associated with the registration based on factors such as the user's location, device, behavior, and other contextual information. If the risk level is deemed high, additional verification measures may be required (e.g. video verification, manual review, etc.).
17. System uses machine learning fraud detection to analyze the registration information and detect patterns or anomalies that may indicate fraudulent activity.
18. If the registration information is deemed suspicious by the fraud detection system, the system flags the registration for manual review by a human fraud analyst.
19. The human fraud analyst reviews the registration information and makes a determination as to its validity. If the registration is deemed invalid or fraudulent, the registration process is terminated. If the registration is deemed valid, the system continues to the next step.
20. If the registration information is deemed valid, system displays a confirmation message to the user, notifying them that their digital identity has been created.

Note: AI-powered identification document reading can significantly speed up the registration process and improve accuracy. However, human oversight is necessary to catch errors and ensure that fraudulent activity is detected. The specific machine learning models and OCR techniques used will depend on the type of identification documents being processed and the requirements of the particular system. Additionally, the human fraud analyst may use additional validation checks, such as contacting the user directly, to further confirm the user's identity.

from transformers import RobertaForSequenceClassification, RobertaTokenizerFast
from sklearn.model_selection import KFold
from datasets import load_dataset, concatenate_datasets
from transformers import TrainingArguments, Trainer, EarlyStoppingCallback, CosineAnnealingLR
from sklearn.metrics import f1_score
import math

# Load dataset
train_dataset = load_dataset("csv", data_files={"train": "./data/train.csv"}, delimiter=",")["train"]
val_dataset = load_dataset("csv", data_files={"validation": "./data/val.csv"}, delimiter=",")["validation"]
dataset = concatenate_datasets([train_dataset, val_dataset])

# Load tokenizer and encode the dataset
tokenizer = RobertaTokenizerFast.from_pretrained('roberta-base')
def encode_dataset(d):
    return tokenizer(d['text'], padding='max_length', truncation=True, max_length=512)
dataset = dataset.map(encode_dataset)

# Define training arguments
training_args = TrainingArguments(
    output_dir='./results',          # output directory
    per_device_train_batch_size=32,  # batch size per device during training
    per_device_eval_batch_size=64,   # batch size for evaluation
    warmup_steps=0,                  # number of warmup steps for learning rate scheduler
    weight_decay=0.01,               # strength of weight decay
    logging_dir='./logs',            # directory for storing logs
    logging_steps=10,
    evaluation_strategy='steps',     # evaluation strategy to adopt during training
    eval_steps=50,                   # number of steps between evaluations
    save_total_limit=3,              # maximum number of checkpoints to save
    save_strategy='steps',           # save checkpoint every eval_steps
    load_best_model_at_end=True,     # load the best model when finished training
    metric_for_best_model='f1',      # use f1-score to evaluate the best model
    lr_scheduler_type='cosine',      # use the cosine annealing learning rate scheduler
    learning_rate=5e-5,
    num_train_epochs=3,              # total number of training epochs
)

# Define k-fold cross-validation
kfold = KFold(n_splits=5, shuffle=True, random_state=42)

for fold, (train_indices, val_indices) in enumerate(kfold.split(dataset)):
    # Split the dataset into train and validation sets for this fold
    train_dataset = dataset.select(train_indices)
    val_dataset = dataset.select(val_indices)

    # Load model and prepare the Trainer
    model = RobertaForSequenceClassification.from_pretrained('roberta-base', num_labels=8)
    
    # Define the learning rate scheduler
    num_training_steps = math.ceil(len(train_dataset) / training_args.per_device_train_batch_size) * training_args.num_train_epochs
    lr_scheduler = CosineAnnealingLR(optimizer.optimizer, T_max=num_training_steps)

    trainer = Trainer(
        model=model,
        args=training_args,
        train_dataset=train_dataset,
        eval_dataset=val_dataset,
        compute_metrics=lambda p: {'f1': f1_score(p.label_ids, p.predictions.argmax(axis=-1), average='micro')},
        callbacks=[EarlyStoppingCallback(early_stopping_patience=1)],
        lr_scheduler=lr_scheduler
    )

    # Train the model for this fold
    trainer.train()
```

EXERCISE 2
The Bridge
The bridge accomplishes several things. It wakes up the gluteal muscles (the big muscles in your buttocks). It reinforces spinal stabilization. It builds endurance and strength in the muscles on the front and back of the core. And it is the precursor to doing a proper squat, which comes later in the book. 
Do the bridge as follows:
Step 1: Lie on your back, with your arms at your side, legs hip-width apart.
Step 2: Find your neutral spine and brace your core to lock it in.

Step 3: Bend your knees and put your feet in a flexed position so that your heels are on the ground and the balls of your feet and toes are off of the ground as pictured.
Step 4: Squeeze your buttocks together as if you were trying to pinch a coin between them.

Step 5: Here’s the tricky part: Using the glutes, lift your hips/torso off of the ground without moving your lower back. You should not articulate the spine and roll up “one vertebra at a time.” You want to do the opposite of that. You want to lift the torso in one solid piece while maintaining your neutral spine. No movement should take place in the lower back.
Step 6: Hold for five to ten seconds (remember these are suggestions. Hold to your tolerance in the beginning, with ten seconds being your goal). You should feel the muscles in both sides of your buttocks working relatively equally.
Step 7: Lower your back down to the starting position without losing your neutral spine. Again, do not articulate the spine on the way down. In other words, do not roll the spine down onto the floor one vertebra at a time.
Step 8: Repeat Steps 2 through 7, and do five to ten reps, with ten being your long-term goal.
TROUBLESHOOTING
• Hamstring cramping. If your hamstrings cramp (the muscles that run down the underside of your thighs), gently push your feet into the floor away from you before you lift your hips/torso off the ground.
• Knee pain. If one or both of your knees hurt, lightly press your knees outward before lifting your hips/torso off the ground.
• Unable to maintain neutral spine. Start by trying to lift your hips/torso only an inch off the ground. Slowly progress to a full bridge over the next few weeks.
• Unable to feel glutes working. Go to Chapter 13. Then come back and start with the following regression.
• If your back hurts with this exercise, proceed to the Buttock Squeezes regression on the next page. Try these for a few days or weeks and then come back and try the bridge again, making sure to follow instructions meticulously. If your back still hurts, you may have a spinal condition like severe stenosis that makes you sensitive to extension in the spine. If this is the case, this exercise might not be for you.
Common Mistakes
The most common mistake for back patients with the bridge exercise is that they use their hamstrings instead of their glutes to bring the hips up into position. If your hamstrings are cramping, then you aren’t using your glutes enough. Go to Chapter 13 and practice “waking up your glutes,” and then come back to this exercise and try it again.
REGRESSION
Buttock Squeezes
If you don’t have the strength or control yet to perform a single bridge exercise properly for any amount of time, start with buttock squeezes.
1. Lie on your back, with arms at your side, knees bent, feet hip-width apart.
2. Find your neutral spine and brace your core to lock it in.
3. Squeeze your buttocks together as if trying to squeeze a coin between them.
4. Hold for ten seconds.
5. Do ten reps.
PROGRESSION
One-Leg Bridge
Once you have mastered the bridge and are able to do it with relative ease and with no discomfort in the back, you may want to progress to the one-leg bridge. You do not have to progress to this exercise. Depending on your spinal condition and your fitness level, you may not need to progress this far. This progression is for those who are reasonably fit and plan to be very active in sports, exercise, or outdoor activities.
1. Follow all rules for the bridge.
2. Once your hips and torso are off the ground, give extra care to make sure your core is braced as firmly as possible.

3. Slowly extend one leg at the knee without letting the hips/torso drop on that side. You will feel the glutes of the other stabilizing leg kick in as you extend the leg.
4. Hold five to ten seconds.
5. Slowly bring the extended leg back to the bent-knee starting position. (Do not lower your hips/torso while doing this. Maintain the bridge position with a neutral spine until your foot is back on the floor.)
6. Slowly lower your hips/torso back to the starting position on the floor without articulating the spine.
7. On the other side, repeat Steps 1 through 6, making sure to come up into a full bridge and lock your core in place before extending the leg at the knee.
Common Mistakes
• When you go to one leg, it is easy to “cock” your hips to one side, to make it easier. Don’t do that. Keep your thighs parallel during the whole exercise. If you can’t, you aren’t strong enough yet for this exercise.
• Regarding extending the leg as you come up/bending the leg down as you go down: Make sure to come up into a full bridge and lock your spine before you try to extend the leg. Conversely, make sure you bring the leg all the way back in before coming down to the starting position.
• Do not bring the thigh of the extended leg up. Make sure your thighs remain parallel so that you have to use the gluteal muscles to keep the pelvis stable.
EXERCISE 3
Crunch and Plank
We discuss these two exercises together because they both do a lot of the same things, and some of you will not get to the plank and that’s okay. The plank will take you a bit further toward returning to strenuous activities, but the crunch is enough to get you out of pain. The purpose of the crunch and the plank is to build endurance and strength in the abdominal wall (crunch and plank) and glutes and lats (plank) and to increase spinal stability. Very few back pain sufferers are strong enough to do a plank properly in the beginning and must do crunches for a while before attempting the plank.
Crunch
First of all, this exercise is not a sit-up. Sit-ups (the traditional “Army sit-up,” where you pull yourself into a full sitting position) have been proven to be very risky to the spine. They run dangerous loads through the lumbar discs. If you wanted to develop a way to herniate a disc in a lab, a sit-up would be a good candidate for it. Crunches, unlike full sit-ups, do not allow movement in the lumbar spine. Your lumbar spine stays in neutral throughout.
Step 1: Lie on your back, with your arms at your side, legs hip-width apart.
Step 2: Find your neutral spine and brace your core to lock it in.

Step 3: Place your hands behind your head, if possible. If you can’t, because of shoulder discomfort, that’s okay. Find a comfortable position for your hands.
Step 4: Gently draw your chin in toward your neck, giving yourself a “double chin.” Hold this position throughout the exercise.
Step 5: Slowly and carefully raise your shoulder blades and head toward the ceiling an inch or two, giving a moderate squeeze in the abdominal muscles without flattening or rounding your lower back. Keep a neutral spine; this will be harder than you think. Only bring your shoulders off the floor as far as you can without moving your lower back. The max distance, when you’re great at it, would be no more than, say, four inches.

Step 6: Hold five to ten seconds, with ten being the goal.
Step 7: Slowly return to the starting position without moving your lower back.
Step 8: Repeat Steps 1 through 7, for five to ten reps, with ten being the goal.
TROUBLESHOOTING
“My neck hurts.” First, you shouldn’t be pulling your head with your arms. Your arms/hands are there only to provide a little support to your head and neck. Make sure that you pull your chin in toward your neck before initiating the exercise. This will engage your deep neck flexors that support the spine. If this does not relieve neck pain, move to the Regression.
Common Mistakes
• The most common mistake is flattening or (worse) rounding the back. It is crucial that you not make this mistake. Doing crunches while continually rounding or flattening the back will promote spinal instability, the opposite of our goal. Details matter!
• Chin jutting. If your chin is poking out toward the ceiling with each rep, you are not stabilizing your cervical spine and your neck extensors are taking over. Make sure to draw the chin in toward your neck before each rep.
REGRESSION
Abdominal Contractions
Do this exercise until you build up enough abdominal strength to accomplish the crunch.
1. Start in the same position as for the bridge.
2. Place one hand behind your lower back and one hand inside your front hipbone beside your navel.
3. Squeeze your abdominal muscles without flattening or rounding your back. You should feel your back being still with one hand and the abs engaging with the other hand.
4. Hold for five to ten seconds, with ten being the goal.
5. Repeat for several reps until fatigue sets in.
PROGRESSION
Plank
Once you have mastered the crunch and are able to do crunches with relative ease and without pain or movement in the lower back, try the plank. This is a great exercise to build increased core stability, endurance, and strength. Some of you (especially those with severe stenosis) may never be able to do a plank. That’s okay. Give the plank a try, and if it doesn’t work for you, stay with crunches. If you do go on to the plank, follow the directions closely; most people do this exercise incorrectly.

1. Lie facedown with your forehead on the floor and your arms flat on the floor on either side of you, elbows bent and palms down.
2. Find your neutral spine and engage your core to lock it in.
3. Squeeze your glutes together and squeeze your feet together.

4. Come up onto your forearms and knees with your elbows below your shoulders.
5. Lift your knees off of the floor so you are now on your toes and forearms.
6. “Traction” your forearms into the floor. In other words, press them into the floor and back toward your feet at the same time. Your forearms shouldn’t move; you are just creating a pulling force into the floor and down toward your feet. This should make you feel more contraction in your lats and lower abdominal muscles.

7. Hold for five to ten seconds, with ten being the goal.
8. Slowly put your knees back down first. Do not let your hips/pelvis go to the floor first; this would put your back into extension and may cause pain.
9. Repeat Steps 1 through 8, for two to five reps, with five being the goal.
TROUBLESHOOTING
• “This hurts my lower back.” Some people just can’t do a plank. Even if they do it the right way, it still aggravates their back. If you can’t do a plank, drop it and stick with crunches. But first, be sure that you can’t do it. For example, if your lower back is hurting, try sticking your buttocks in the air a little more. It could be that your hips are sagging toward the floor, putting your back into extension. Also, make sure the core is fully engaged before moving from knees to toes. Lastly, make sure you are squeezing your buttocks, which will support the lower back. If none of that works, forget it; stick with crunches.
• “This hurts my shoulders.” Make sure you are tractioning your forearms down into the floor and back toward your toes. This engages the supportive muscles of the rotator cuff. If this doesn’t help, try the regression that follows.
Common Mistakes
• Feet and legs are not together, which makes gluteal engagement more difficult.
• Back is up but the hips are dropping toward the floor. This will cause back pain in people with conditions such as stenosis or facet syndrome.
• You’re forgetting to pull shoulders back and forearms into the floor with chin jutting. This will cause an increase in pressure in the shoulders and/or neck, resulting in shoulder and neck pain.
REGRESSION
Plank on Knees
If you aren’t quite ready for plank but think crunch is just too easy, try this one.
1. Lie facedown with your forehead on the floor and your arms flat on the floor on either side of you, elbows bent, palms down.
2. Find your neutral spine and engage your core to lock it in.
3. Squeeze your glutes together and squeeze your feet together.
4. Come up onto your forearms and knees with your elbows below your shoulders (see illustration, for the plank).
5. Traction your forearms into the floor, pulling them into the floor and back toward your feet at the same time. Your forearms shouldn’t move; you are just creating a pulling force into the floor and back toward your feet. This should make you feel more contraction in your lats and lower abdominal muscles.
6. Hold for five to ten seconds, with ten being the goal.
EXERCISE 4
Dynamic Hamstring Stretch
CAUTION
This exercise may irritate symptoms of people with active radiculopathy, such as severe leg/foot pain, and numbness or tingling in the legs or feet. If you have these symptoms, start with caution; you may not be able to do this exercise. If this exercise exacerbates your leg or back symptoms, skip it for now and come back to it when the symptoms are resolved.
The dynamic hamstring stretch helps to improve mobility in the hips and also helps to reinforce and strengthen your ability to maintain a neutral spine while moving the legs. It also builds endurance and strength in the core.
Step 1: Lie on your back and find neutral spine.
Step 2: Brace the core to lock in neutral spine.

Step 3: Bend one leg at the knee with your foot flat on floor. Straighten out the other leg onto the floor, with foot flexed (toes pointed up).
Step 4: Carefully raise the straight leg without losing your neutral spine; in other words, make sure your lower back isn’t flattening into the floor as your leg comes up. To check, put one of your hands underneath your lower back and feel for movement. Raise the leg only as high as you can without flattening your back into the floor. 
Step 5: Do ten to twenty repetitions on each leg. Do as many as needed to feel that you have mildly stretched your hamstrings and worked your core.
Common Mistake
Flattening the back into the floor as you bring the leg up. Remember, one of the most important points of these exercises is to teach you neutral spine/spinal stability. You do not want to accomplish an increase of movement speed at the expense of spinal stabilization. Bring up your leg only as high as you can without flattening your back or bending your knee. Increasing hamstring flexibility will come with time.
EXERCISE 5
Side Plank
The side plank works the muscles on the lateral (side) parts of the core, such as the obliques, gluteus medius, and quadratus lumborum. This exercise is a very important one. I mention this because almost everyone hates doing it. But don’t give up: Your back depends on it. Many readers will not be able to do this exercise at first because their core is weak. Don’t worry. There are regressions (easier exercises) for those of you who can’t do this one yet.
Step 1: Start by lying on your side, propped up on your forearm, with your elbow under your shoulder. Relax the other arm for now. Pull your lower arm shoulder blade inward toward your spine and downward toward your buttocks, engaging the lat muscles.
Step 2: Drop your hips back a bit so that they sit behind your feet and shoulders.
